newsitem.title: USA: U.S. corp bond issuers gear up to come to market.
newsitem.headline: U.S. corp bond issuers gear up to come to market.

text.p: A slew of new issues are expected to rain down on the corporate bond arena as issuers gear up to bring debt to market, dealers said.
"The tone in the market is very optimistic...we're seeing quite a bit of issuance coming to market," said one syndicate source.
Dealers said many names are circulating the new issue arena; but it's difficult to gauge how much business will come as no official dates have been set on upcoming deals.
"We're hearing a lot of names in the market but it's tough to peg when these deals are coming because no official calendar exists," another syndicate source said.
Dealers expect a recent drop in U.S. Treasury yields to spur more issuers to tap the primary market while the rate environment remains favorable for financing debt.
The following issues are expected to come to market, syndicate sources said.
Union Pacific Resources is expected to price $400 million in A3/A-rated two-part debt consisting of $200 million in 10-year debt and $200 million of 30-year debt.
Loewen Group is expected to price $350 million in a two-part senior guaranteed notes deal consisting of $175 million five-year debt and $175 million seven-year debt via Smith Barney.
Medpartners is also expected to tap the market with $300 million in Baa3/BBB-rated 10-year debt also via Smith Barney.
Allegiance Healthcare is expected to issue $500 million in a three-part debt via Goldman Sachs.
Airtouch Communications is expected to tap the market with $250 million in seven-year debt via Lehman Brothers.

Among foreign issuers, Argentina launched its $750 million 10-year bond issue via joint lead managers Goldman Sachs and Salomon Brothers. Price talk on the issue is 445 to 450 basis points over the 10-year U.S. Treasury note.
"I'm hearing the Argentina deal is a blowout in London," said one high-grade syndicate source in New York.
Brazil is also expected to price $750 million in global debt in a five or ten-year maturity this week, dealers said.
In addition, South Africa is gearing up to launch its first yankee issue ever via Merrill Lynch, sources added.
